Description: Terracotta figure in the form of a uraeus. Hand-modelled from Nile silt clay, fired to orange-red, the figure represents a rearing cobra with flared hood, sat upon a flat support. The figure sits well upon an even surface. Three applied features have been added to the front of the figure, prior to firing: an offering stand/vessel (?) flanked by miniature cobras. The figure still bears traces of its original painted decoration, in white, yellow and black pigment. A section lost from under the head has been re-affixed; some repair-work at the back.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amarna, el-, Excavation number 22/130 From house no.8, Long Wall Street, Workman's Village
Curator's comments: Excavation report: Peet and Woolley, City of Akhenaten I (1923): 84, pl.23 Published, with parallels: Szpakowska, JARCE 40 (2003): 116-17, figs.4-7 Such figures are found in domestic, temple and funerary contexts, and are a distinctive feature of Egyptian material culture of the late New Kingdom and Third Intermediate Period. Being hand-modelled and made from readily available material, it is unsurprising that their form and scale vary enormously. See Spencer, Kom Firin I (2008), 64-5 for discussion of such figures (with further references).
